statement.p: Consider a car whose position, s, is given by the table
Find the average velocity over the interval 0 \le t \le 0.2.
average velocity =
Estimate the velocity at t=0.2.
velocity =

static.solution:
0 \le t \le 0.2 is given by
\frac{s(0.2)-s(0)}{0.2}=\frac{0.5}{0.2}=2.5 ft/s.
The average velocity over the interval 0.2 \le t \le 0.4 is given by
\frac{s(0.4)-s(0.2)}{0.2}=\frac{1.4-0.5}{0.2}=4.5 ft/s.
A reasonable estimate for the velocity at t=0.2 is the average \frac{1}{2}\cdot (2.5+4.5) = 3.5 ft/s.

statement.p: The table below shows the number of calories used per minute as a function of an individual's body weight for three sports:
a) Determine the number of calories that a 200 lb person uses in one half-hour of walking . calories

b) Who uses more calories, a 170 lb person swimming for one hour, or a 220 lb person bicycling for a half-hour?
The 170 lb person swimming for one hour
The 220 lb person bicycling for a half-hour
They both use the same amount of calories

c) Does the number of calories of a person walking increase or decrease as weight increases?
Increase
Decrease

static.solution:
SOLUTION
a) The table gives the amount of calories used per minute. So in order to find the total number of calories used in a half-hour, use the table to find the number of calories used by a 200 lb who walks for a half-hour, and then multiply by 30 minutes. Using the table we know a 200 lb person walking uses 5.4 calories per minute; therefore, \mbox{ Total calories used } = ( 5.4 )(30) = 162 \mbox{ calories}
b) Using the same calculation as in (a), it follows that a 170 lb person swimming uses 9.8 calories per minute. Thus a 170 lb person swimming for one hour uses a total of ( 9.8 )(60) = 588 calories. On the other hand, a 220 lb person bicycling uses 11.9 calories per minute. Thus a 220 lb person bicycling for a half-hour uses a total of ( 11.9 )(30) = 357 calories. By comparing the values 588 and 357 we obtain the answer.
c) Since the values in the table are increasing along the row of values corresponding to a person who is walking, the number of calories of a person walking increases as weight increases.

statement.p: Let \ f(x) = 9 - x^2.
a) Compute each of the following expressions and interpret each as an average rate of change:

b) Based on the graph sketched below, match each of your answers in (i) - (iii) with one of the lines labeled A - F. Type the corresponding letter of the line segment next to the appropriate formula. Clearly not all letters will be used.
(click on image to enlarge)

static.solution:
SOLUTION
a)
i) \frac{f( 1 ) - f(0)}{ 1 - 0} = \frac{ 8 - 9 }{1 - 0} = \frac{ -1 }{ 1} = -1
ii) \frac{f( 3 ) - f( 1 ) }{ 3 - 1 } = \frac{ 0 - 8}{3 - 1} = \frac{ -8 }{ 2} = -4
iii) \frac{f( 3 ) - f(0)}{ 3 - 0} = \frac{ 0 - 9 }{ 3 - 0} = \frac{ -8 }{ 3} = -3
b) The formulas in parts (i), (ii), and (iii) represent the average rate of change of f(x) over the intervals 0 \leq x \leq 1 , 1 \leq x \leq 3 , and 0 \leq x \leq 3 respectively. Thus line segment D connecting the points (0, 9 ) and ( 1, 8 ) illustrates formula (i), line segment C connecting the points ( 1, 8 ) and ( 3, 0 ) illustrates formula (ii), and line segment B connecting the points (0, 9 ) and ( 3, 0 ) illustrates formula (iii).

statement.p: Consider the graphs of f(x) and g(x) below:
For each interval given below, decide whether the average rate of change of f(x) or g(x) is greater over that particular interval.

row.cell: Which function has GREATER average rate of change?

var.name: AnSwEr0001
var.li: both have an equal rate of change

var.name: AnSwEr0002
var.li: both have an equal rate of change

var.name: AnSwEr0003
var.li: both have an equal rate of change

var.name: AnSwEr0004
var.li: both have an equal rate of change

var.name: AnSwEr0005
var.li: both have an equal rate of change

static.solution:
SOLUTION
Since the graph of g(x) is a line, its average rate of change is the same over all intervals. Since the graph of g(x) is going up, its average rate of change is always positive. The average rate of change of f(x) is clearly changing depending on the interval. If the slope of the line connecting the two endpoints of the interval on f(x) is going up and is steeper than the slope of g(x), then the average rate of change of f(x) will be greater over that interval. If the line connecting the two endpoints points on f(x) is less steep, horizontal, or going down, then the average rate of change of g(x) will greater over that interval. If the slope of the line connecting to endpoints of the interval on f(x) is the same as the slope of g(x), then the two average rates of change will be equal (such as the case for the interval 2.2 \leq x \leq 6.1. Based on this consideration, you should determine the following answers:
Interval Which function has GREATER average rate of change?
0 \leq x \leq 4 g
0 \leq x \leq 8 g
0 \leq x \leq 2.2 f
5.2 \leq x \leq 6.1 f
5.2 \leq x \leq 6.9 g

statement.p: A car is driven at a constant speed, starting at noon. Which of the following could be a graph of the distance the car has traveled as a function of time past noon?
figure .

solution.p: SOLUTION

Because the car is driven at a constant speed, the change in the distance traveled is the same for different time intervals of the same length. Thus the graph of the distance traveled must have a constant positive slope, and must be graph 3.

statement.p: Use the figure below, which gives a graph of the function f(x), to give values for the indicated limits. If a limit does not exist, enter none.
(a) \lim\limits_{x \rightarrow -1} f(x) =
(b) \lim\limits_{x \rightarrow 0} f(x) =
(c) \lim\limits_{x \rightarrow 1} f(x) =
(d) \lim\limits_{x \rightarrow 4} f(x) =

static.solution:
(a) As x approaches -1 from either side, the values of f(x) get closer and closer to 6, so the limit appears to be about 6.
(b) As x approaches 0 from either side, the values of f(x) get closer and closer to 7. (Recall that to find a limit, we are interested in what happens to the function near x but not at x.) The limit appears to be about 7.
(c) As x approaches 1 from either side, the values of f(x) get closer and closer to 6 on one side of x = 1 and get closer and closer to -8 on the other side of x = 1. Thus the limit does not exist.
(d) As x approaches 4 from either side, the values of f(x) get closer and closer to -2. (Again, recall that we don't care what happens right at x = 4.) The limit appears to be about -2.

Consider the function y = f(x) graphed below.
Give the x-coordinate of a point where:
A. the derivative of the function is negative: x =
B. the value of the function is negative: x =
C. the derivative of the function is smallest (most negative): x =
D. the derivative of the function is zero: x =
E. the derivative of the function is approximately the same as the derivative at x = 2.25 (be sure that you give a point that is distinct from x = 2.25!): x =

static.solution:
A. Recall that the derivative is negative when the function is decreasing. So we're looking for a point on the graph where the function is decreasing; one such point is x = 1.
B. The function is negative when the function is below the x-axis. One such point is x = 1.5.
C. The derivative of the function is smallest (most negative) when the function is decreasing the fastest. This occurs at x \approx 3.25.
D. The derivative of the function is zero when the function has a horizontal tangent. One such point is x \approx 1.45.
E. Finally, we're looking for a point where the derivative is the same as the derivative at x = 2.25. This means that we want the slope of a tangent to the curve to be approximately the same as it is at x = 2.25. Such a point is x = 1.75.

statement.p: The figure below shows a function g(x) and its tangent line at the point B = (6.8,2). If the point A on the tangent line is (6.74,2.05), fill in the blanks below to complete the statements about the function g at the point B.

static.solution: B=(6.8,2) is on the graph of g, we have g(6.8)=2. The slope of the tangent line touching the graph at x=2 is given by \mbox{slope} = \frac{\mbox{rise}}{\mbox{run}} = \frac{2-2.05}{6.8-6.74} = -0.833. Thus, g'(6.8)=-0.833.

statement.p: Consider the graph of the function f(x) shown below.
Using this graph, for each of the following pairs of numbers decide which is larger. Be sure that you can explain your answer.

static.solution:
A. Since f is increasing, f(6) < f(8).
B. From the figure, it appears that f(6) - f(4) > f(4) - f(2).
C. The quantity \frac{f(4)-f(2)}{4-2} represents the slope of the secant line connecting the points on the graph at x=2 and x=4. This is less than the slope of the secant line connecting the points at x=2 and x=6, which is \frac{f(6)-f(2)}{6-2}
D. The function is less steep at x=2 than at x=8, so f'(2) < f'(8).

statement.p: Find the derivative of g(t) = 2 t^2 + 2 t at t=7 algebraically.
Estimate f'(3) for f(x) = 6^x. Be sure your answer is accurate to within 0.1 of the actual value.

p.em: Be sure that you can explain your reasoning.

static.solution: f'(3) using the average rate of change formula on a small interval around 3. Let's try the interval from x = 3 to x = 3 + 0.0001. Then we have f'(3) \approx {f(3+0.0001) - f(3)\over 0.0001} = {6^{3.0001} - 6^{3}\over 0.0001} \approx 387, rounded to one decimal place. We can check that this is accurate to within 0.1 by testing a smaller interval, say from x = 3 to x = 3 + 0.00001. For this, we have f'(3) \approx {f(3+0.00001) - f(3)\over 0.00001} = {6^{3.00001} - 6^{3}\over 0.00001} \approx 387. This agrees with our previous result to one decimal place, so f'(3)\approx 387 is a good estimate.

statement.p: (b) What are the units of f'(35)?

Suppose that |f'(35)| = 1.5 and f(35) = 68. Fill in the blanks (including units where needed) and select the appropriate terms to complete the following statement about the temperature of the coffee in this case.

At minutes after the coffee was put on the counter, its
?
derivative
temperature
change in temperature
is and will
?

decrease
by about in the next 30 seconds.

p.alert: Note: If you are using MathQuill click the textbox (Tt) button before entering an answer that contains units.

static.solution:
(a) As the cup of coffee cools, the temperature decreases, so f'(t) is negative.
(b) Since f'(t) = dH/dt, the units are degrees Celsius per minute (degC/min). The quantity f'(35) represents the rate at which the coffee is cooling, in degrees per minute, 35 minutes after the cup is put on the counter. Thus we can complete the statement:
At 35 minutes after the coffee was put on the counter, its temperature is 68 degC and will decrease by about 0.75 degC in the next 30 seconds.

static.solution:
W=f(c) where W is weight in pounds and c is the number of Calories consumed per day:
(a) f(1600) = 165 means that consuming 1600 cal each day results in a weight of 165 lb (the units of 1600 are cal, and 165 lb).
(b) f'(2000)=0 means that consuming 2000 cal each day causes neither weight gain nor loss (the units of the 2000 are cal, and 0 lb/cal).
(c) f^{-1}(173)=2400 means that a weight of 173 lb is caused by a consumption of 2400 cal each day (the units of 173 are lb, and 2400 cal).
(d) The units of dW/dc are lb/cal
(e) Based on Sam's conclusion, f'(2800) should equal \frac{\Delta W}{\Delta c} = \frac{0.8}{40} = 0.02.

statement.p: At exactly two of the labeled points in the figure below, which shows a function f, the derivative f' is zero; the second derivative f'' is not zero at any of the labeled points. Select the correct signs for each of f, f' and f'' at each marked point.

static.solution:
f is positive, negative, or zero by whether the point is plotted above, below, or on the x-axis. The sign of f' is determined by the slope of the function at the point: if the function is increasing, then f'>0; if it is decreasing, f'\lt 0, and if it is neither increasing nor decreasing, then f'=0. Similarly, the sign of f'' is determined by the concavity of the function: if the function is concave up, then f''>0, if it is concave down, f''\lt 0. This gives the table
Point A B C D E
f zero negative zero positive positive
f' negative zero positive zero negative
f'' positive positive positive negative negative

statement.p: Suppose that f(x) is a function with f(130) = 46 and f'(130) = 1. Estimate f(125.5).

static.solution: f(130) = 46 and f'(130) = 1 tell us that at x = 130, the value of the function is 46 and the function is increasing at a rate of 1 units for a unit increase in x. Since we increase x by -4.5 units in going from 130 to 125.5, the value of the function goes up by approximately -4.5 \cdot 1 = -4.5 units, so f(125.5) \approx 46 - 4.5 \cdot 1 = 46 - 4.5 = 41.5.

static.solution:
(a) As the cup of coffee cools, the temperature decreases, so f'(t) is negative.
(b) Since f'(t) = dH/dt, the units are degrees Celsius per minute (degC/min). The quantity f'(30) represents the rate at which the coffee is cooling, in degrees per minute, 30 minutes after the cup is put on the counter. Thus we can complete the statement:
At 30 minutes after the coffee was put on the counter, its temperature is 51 degC and will decrease by about 1.125 degC in the next 75 seconds.

For x>0, find and simplify the derivative of f(x) = \arctan x + \arctan(1/x).
(What does your result tell you about f)?

static.solution:
f'(x) = \frac{1}{1+x^2}+\frac{1}{1+\frac{1}{x^2}}\cdot (-\frac{1}{x^2}), or, simplifying the second term, f'(x) = \frac{1}{1+x^2}+\left(-\frac{1}{x^2+1}\right) = \frac{1}{1+x^2}-\frac{1}{1+x^2} = 0.
Thus f is a constant function! We can check a few values to confirm this: f(1) = \arctan(1) + \arctan(1) \approx 0.785392 + 0.7853982 = 1.5707963,
f(2) = \arctan(2) + \arctan(\frac12) \approx 1.1071487 + 0.4636476 = 1.5707963, and
f(3) = \arctan(3) + \arctan(\frac13) \approx 1.2490458 + 0.3217506 = 1.5707963.

statement.p: Let (x_0, y_0) = (2, 6) and (x_1, y_1) = (2.1, 6.2). Use the following graph of the function f to find the indicated derivatives.
If h(x)=(f(x))^{5}, then
If g(x)=f^{-1}(x), then

static.solution:
(2,6) is on the curve, we know f(2)=6. The point (2.1,6.2) is on the tangent line, so \hbox{Slope of tangent} = \frac{6.2-6}{2.1-2} = \frac{0.2}{0.1} = 2. Thus, f'(2)=2.
By the chain rule h'(2) = 5(f(2))^{4}\cdot f'(2) =5\cdot 6^{4}\cdot 2 = 12960.
Because g(x) is the inverse function of f, we know that g(6) = 2. Then note that f(g(x)) = f(f^{-1}(x)) = x, so f(g(x)) = x. Differentiating both sides of the equation, f'(g(x))\cdot g'(x) = 1, so g'(x) = \frac{1}{f'(g(x))}. Thus g'(6) = \frac{1}{f'(g(6))} = \frac{1}{f'(2)} = \frac1{2}.

statement.p: Let f(x) = \displaystyle 8\cos\!\left(x\right)\sin^{-1}\!\left(x\right). Find f'(x).
Find dy/dx in terms of x and y if x^{2} y - x - 5 y - 11 =0.

solution.p: We differentiate implicitly with respect to x. This gives 2 x y - x^{2} \, \frac{dy}{dx} - 1 - 5 \, \frac{dy}{dx} = 0, or (x^{2}-5) \, \frac{dy}{dx} = 1-2xy, and so \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{1 - 2 x y}{x^{2} - 5}.

We differentiate implicitly both sides of the equation with respect to x. \ln y + \frac xy \, \frac{dy}{dx} + 3 y^{2}\frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{3}{x}, so \left( \frac{x}{y} + 3 y^{2} \right) \, \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{3}{x} - \ln y, and thus \frac{dy}{dx} = \frac{\frac{3}{x} - \ln y}{\frac{x}{y} + 3 y^{2}} = \frac{y\!\left(3-x\ln\!\left(y\right)\right)}{x\!\left(x+3y^{3}\right)}.

statement.p: Find dy/dx in terms of x and y if \arctan(x^{3} y) = x y^{3}.

p.em: (Enter undef if the slope is not defined at this point.)

solution.p: Differentiating with respect to x gives 3 x^{2} + y + x y' + 2y y'=0 so that y' = -\frac{3 x^{2} + y}{ x + 2 y}.
At the point (1,5) the slope is - \frac{3\cdot 1^{2}+5}{1+2\cdot 5} = -{\frac{8}{11}}.

statement.p: Use implicit differentiation to find an equation of the tangent line to the curve 3xy^{3}+xy = 16 at the point \left(4,1\right).
The equation defines the tangent line to the curve at the point \left(4,1\right).

solution.p: Differentiating implicitly with respect to x gives 3 y^3 + 9 x y^2 \, \frac{dy}{dx} + y + x \, \frac{dy}{dx} = 0. If x = 4 and y = 1, then this equation becomes 4 + 40 \, \frac{dy}{dx} = 0, \qquad \text{and so} \qquad \frac{dy}{dx} = -{\frac{1}{10}}. If (x, y) is any point on the tangent line besides \left(4,1\right) then -{\frac{1}{10}} = \frac{y-1}{x-4}, \qquad \text{or} \qquad 1\!\left(x-4\right) = -10\!\left(y-1\right). Therefore, x+10y = 14 is an equation of the line tangent to the curve at the point \left(4,1\right).

Use a graph below of f(x) = \ln(2 x^2 + 1) to estimate the x-values of any critical points and inflection points of f(x).
critical points (enter as a comma-separated list): x =
inflection points (enter as a comma-separated list): x =
Next, use derivatives to find the x-values of any critical points and inflection points exactly.
critical points (enter as a comma-separated list): x =
inflection points (enter as a comma-separated list): x =

solution.p: SOLUTION
From the graph, we see that f(x) appears to have one critical point, at x=0, and two inflection points, one between 0 and 1 and the other between 0 and -1.
To find the critical points, we set f'(x) = 0. Since f'(x) = {2(2)x\over 2 x^2 + 1} = 0, there is one solution, x = 0. The only critical point is at x=0.

To find the inflection points, we find f''(x) and determine where it is zero. f''(x) = {4 (2 x^2 + 1) - 16 x^2\over(2 x^2+1)^2} = {4( 1 - 2 x^2 )\over(2 x^2+1)^2}. For this to be zero, we must have -1 + 2 x^2 = 0, or x = \pm 1/\sqrt{2}. There are exactly two inflection points, at x = -1/\sqrt{2} \approx -0.707 and x = 1/\sqrt{2} \approx 0.707.

statement.p: Find the inflection points of f(x)=4 x^4 + 55 x^3 - 21 x^2 + 3. (Give your answers as a comma separated list, e.g., 3,-2.)
inflection points =

solution.p: SOLUTION

We find inflection points by determining where f''(x) changes sign. f'(x) = 4\cdot 4x^{3}+55\cdot 3x^{2}-21\cdot 2x, so f''(x) = 4\cdot 4\cdot 3x^{2}+55\cdot 3\cdot 2x-42 = 6(8 x - 1)(x + 7). So we see that f''(x) changes sign at x = 1/8 and x = -7.

statement.p: The following shows graphs of three functions, A (in black), B (in blue), and C (in green). If these are the graphs of three functions f, f', and f'', identify which is which.

p.em: (Click on the graph to get a larger version.)

statement.p: (For each enter A, B or C).

solution.p: SOLUTION

To determine which graphed function is the the derivative of another, we use the fact that the derivative is zero where the original function has a maximum or minimum. We note that C has zeros where B has a maximum or minimum, so it could be the derivative, so we can have C = B'. In addition, B has zeros where A has a maximum or minimum, so that it is possible that B = A'.
To confirm this, we compare intervals where B is increasing and decreasing and verify that these are where C is positive and negative, respectively, and similarly compare A and B.
This gives us that f = A, f' = B, and f'' = C.

statement.p: For some positive constant C, a patient's temperature change, T, due to a dose, D, of a drug is given by T = \left(\frac{C}{2} - \frac{D}{3}\right)D^2.
What dosage maximizes the temperature change?
The sensitivity of the body to the drug is defined as dT/dD. What dosage maximizes sensitivity?

solution.p: SOLUTION
We have T(D) = \left(\frac{C}{2} - \frac{D}{3}\right)D^2 = \frac{CD^2}{2}-\frac{D^3}{3}, and so \frac{dT}{dD} = CD-D^2 = D(C-D).
Since, by this formula, dT/dD is zero when D=0 or D=C, negative when D>C, and positive when D\lt C, we have (by the first derivative test) that the temperature change is maximized when D=C.

The sensitivity is dT/dD = CD-D^2; its derivative is d^2T/dD^2 = C-2D, which is zero if D= C/2, negative if D> C/2, and positive if D\lt C/2. Thus by the first derivative test the sensitivity is maximized at D=C/2.

p.em: (Enter your answer as an interval, or union of intervals, giving the possible values. Thus if you know -5 \lt g(0) \le -2, enter (-5,-2]. Enter infinity for \infty, the interval [1,1] to indicate a single point).

statement.p: How is the value of g(2) related to the value of g(0)?

p.em: (Enter the appropriate mathematical equality or inequality, =, \lt , >, etc.)

solution.p: SOLUTION

Because the graph of g'(x) is negative for all -2 \lt x \lt 2, we know that the graph of g(x) must always be decreasing there. The derivative appears to be zero at x = \pm 2, so the graph of g(x) must start out flat at x = -2, and then decreases more and more rapidly as it approaches x = 0. After x = 0 the it decreases less rapidly, finally flattening out entirely as we get to x = 2.
A. The graph has an inflection point at x = 0, where the slope changes from negative and decreasing to negative and increasing.
B. The function has a global maximum at x=-2 and a global minimum at x=2.

C. Since the function is decreasing over the interval -2 \lt x \lt 2, we know that g(0) must be less than g(-2), and so must be in the interval (-\infty,-8). (We note that it appears that the magnitude of the derivative g' is also less than one for the entire domain that we are considering, so we can actually give a smaller interval for the possible values of g; any interval between (-\infty,-8) and (-10,-8) is reasonable.)
D. Again, since the function is decreasing over the interval -2 \lt x \lt 2, we know that g(-2) = -8 > g(0) > g(2).

statement.p: An open box is to be made out of a 10-inch by 18-inch piece of cardboard by cutting out squares of equal size from the four corners and bending up the sides. Find the dimensions of the resulting box that has the largest volume.

Height of the box:

A rectangular storage container with an open top is to have a volume of 26 cubic meters. The length of its base is twice the width. Material for the base costs 11 dollars per square meter. Material for the sides costs 9 dollars per square meter. Find the cost of materials for the cheapest such container.
Total cost = (Round to the nearest penny and include monetary units. For example, if your answer is 1.095, enter $1.10 including the dollar sign and second decimal place.)

solution.p: SOLUTION
Let w and h denote the width of the base and the height of the container, respectively.

Since the length of the base is twice the width, the volume of the container is V= (2w)(w)h =2 w^2 h = 26 so h = \frac{26}{ 2 w^2} The sides have total area 2(2w)h+ 2wh = 6wh, while the base has area w(2w) = 2 w^2, so the cost is 9 \cdot (6wh ) + 11\cdot (2 w^2) Substuting the expression for h gives C(w) = 9 \cdot 6 w\cdot \frac{26}{ 2 w^2} + 11\cdot( 2 w^2 ) = \frac{702}{w} + 22 w^2 \quad w >0 C'(w) = -\frac{702}{w^2} + 44 w = \frac{-702+ 44 w^3}{w^2} \displaystyle w = \left({\frac{351}{22}}\right)^{1/3} is the critical number. There is an absolute minimum at this critical number since C'(w) \lt 0 for 0 \lt w \lt \left({\frac{351}{22}}\right)^{1/3} and C'(w) >0 for w > \left({\frac{351}{22}}\right)^{1/3}.
The total minimum cost is C\left(\left({\frac{351}{22}}\right)^{1/3} \right) \approx \$418.28

Gravel is being dumped from a conveyor belt at a rate of 10 cubic feet per minute. It forms a pile in the shape of a right circular cone whose base diameter and height are always the same. How fast is the height of the pile increasing when the pile is 23 feet high? Recall that the volume of a right circular cone with height h and radius of the base r is given by V= \frac{1}{3}\pi r^2h.
When the pile is 23 feet high, its height is increasing at feet per minute.

solution.p: We are given that the diameter and height are always the same, so 2r = h,or r = \frac12 h. Hence, the volume of the pile is \textstyle V = \frac13 \pi r^2 h = \frac13 \pi \bigl( \frac12 h \bigr)^2 h = \frac1{12} \pi h^3. Differentiating with respect to time (t) gives \frac{dV}{dt} = {\textstyle \frac{1}{12} \pi \, 3 h^2} \, \frac{dh}{dt} = {\textstyle \frac14 \pi h^2} \, \frac{dh}{dt}, and so \frac{dh}{dt} = \frac{4}{\pi h^2} \frac{dV}{dt}. If \frac{dV}{dt} = 10 and h = 23, then \frac{dh}{dt} = \frac{4 \cdot 10}{23 ^2 \pi} = \frac{40}{529\pi }. Hence, when the pile is 23 feet high its height is increasing at a rate of \frac{40}{529\pi } feet per minute.

statement.p: A street light is at the top of a 13 foot tall pole. A 6 foot tall woman walks away from the pole with a speed of 6 ft/sec along a straight path. How fast is the tip of her shadow moving when she is 30 feet from the base of the pole?
The tip of the shadow is moving at ft/sec.

Water is leaking out of an inverted conical tank at a rate of 9600.0 \textrm{cm}^3/\textrm{min} at the same time that water is being pumped into the tank at a constant rate. The tank has height 7.0 \ \textrm{m} and the the diameter at the top is 5.0 \ \textrm{m}. If the water level is rising at a rate of 22.0 \ \textrm{cm}/\textrm{min} when the height of the water is 1.5 \ \textrm{m}, find the rate at which water is being pumped into the tank in cubic centimeters per minute.
Answer: \textrm{cm}^3/\textrm{min}

static.hint: R be the unknown rate at which water is being pumped in. Then you know that if V is volume of water, \frac{dV}{dt}=R-9600.0. Use geometry (similar triangles) to find the relationship between the height of the water and the volume of the water at any given time. Recall that the volume of a cone with base radius r and height h is given by \frac{1}{3} \pi r^2 h

solution.p: The volume V of a cone of diameter d and height h is V=\frac{\pi d^2 h }{12}. We might as well do this problem a little more generally than stated. (It actually makes things clearer to use variables throughout and substitute specific values only at the end.) So suppose the diameter of our tank is D and its height is H. Suppose the depth of the water is h and the radius of the surface is r. Then, by similar triangles, \frac{r}{h} = \frac{R}{H}, or r= \frac{Rh}{H}. Substituting in the volume formula gives V= \frac{\pi D^2h^3}{12H^2}. Differentiating gives: V'= \frac{3\pi D^2h^2h'}{12H^2} = \frac{\pi D^2h^2h'}{4H^2} This rate of change in volume would be the rate T at which water is being pumped into the tank if there was no leak. However, if L is the leak rate then T = L+\frac{\pi D^2h^2h'}{4H^2}.
Note that since we have to have consistent units of length, and the answer is in cubic centimeters per minute, the lengths given in meters have to be converted to centimeters.
Thus, substituting L = 9600,\quad D = 500,\quad H = 700, \quad h = 150,\quad h' = 22 we obtain T = 9600 + \frac{\pi*500^2*150^2*22}{4*700^2} \approx 207953 \hbox{cm}^3/\hbox{min}.

statement.p: The velocity of a particle moving along the x-axis is given by f(t) = 12 - 4 t cm/sec. Use a graph of f(t) to find the exact change in position of the particle from time t=0 to t=4 seconds.

A
B

Which stops first?
A
B

Which travels farther?
A
B

solution.p: SOLUTION
Car B has a velocity that attains the largest maximum value.
The graph of the velocity of car B returns to zero first, so that car stops first.
The area under the velocity curve for A is largest, so that car travels the farthest.

statement.p: Suppose that an accelerating car goes from 0 mph to 68.2 mph in five seconds. Its velocity is given in the following table, converted from miles per hour to feet per second, so that all time measurements are in seconds. (Note: 1 mph is 22/15 feet per sec = 22/15 ft/s.) Find the average acceleration of the car over each of the first two seconds.
average acceleration over the first second = (include units)
average aceleration over the second second = (include units)

solution.p: SOLUTION

To measure the average acceleration over an interval, we calculate the average rate of change of velocity over the interval. The units of acceleration are ft/s per second, or ft/s/s, written ft/s{}^2. \mbox{average acceleration for } 0\le t\le 1 = \frac{\mbox{Change in velocity}}{\mbox{Change in time}}, so, reading the velocities from the table, we have \frac{v(1) - v(0)}{1} = 34.09 - 0.00 = 34.09 \mbox{ft/s}{}^2. Similarly, \mbox{avg accel for } 1\le t\le 2 = \frac{v(2) - v(1)}{2-1} = 59.09 - 34.09 = 25 \mbox{ft/s}{}^2.

statement.p: Your task is to estimate how far an object traveled during the time interval 0 \leq t \leq 8, but you only have the following data about the velocity of the object.

To get an idea of what the velocity function might look like, you pick up a black pen, plot the data points, and connect them by curves. Your sketch looks something like the black curve in the graph below.

You decide to use a left endpoint Riemann sum to estimate the total displacement. So, you pick up a blue pen and draw rectangles whose height is determined by the velocity measurement at the left endpoint of each one-second interval. By using the left endpoint Riemann sum as an approximation, you are assuming that the actual velocity is approximately constant on each one-second interval (or, equivalently, that the actual acceleration is approximately zero on each one-second interval), and that the velocity and acceleration have discontinuous jumps every second. This assumption is probably incorrect because it is likely that the velocity and acceleration change continuously over time. However, you decide to use this approximation anyway since it seems like a reasonable approximation to the actual velocity given the limited amount of data.
(A) Using the left endpoint Riemann sum, find approximately how far the object traveled. Your answers must include the correct units.
Total displacement =
Total distance traveled =

Using the same data, you also decide to estimate how far the object traveled using a right endpoint Riemann sum. So, you sketch the curve again with a black pen, and draw rectangles whose height is determined by the velocity measurement at the right endpoint of each one-second interval.
(B) Using the right endpoint Riemann sum, find approximately how far the object traveled. Your answers must include the correct units.
Total displacement =
Total distance traveled =

static.solution:
Solution:
Using the left endpoint Riemann sum, the total displacement is the net area of the light blue shaded rectangles, and the total distance is the absolute area of the light blue shaded rectangles.
Total displacement = -4 - 2 - 3+1+2+3+2+3 = 2 feet.
Total distance = |-4|+|-2|+|-3|+|1|+|2|+|3|+|2|+|3| = 20 feet.
We can also make similar calculations using the right endpoint Riemann sum.
Total displacement = -2 - 3+1+2+3+2+3+4 = 10 feet.
Total distance = |-2|+|-3|+|1|+|2|+|3|+|2|+|3|+|4| = 20 feet.

static.solution:
\int_0^2\,f(x)\,dx and \int_0^2\,g(x)\,dx as the area under the curves and dividing by the length of the interval, which is 2. This gives us:
\hbox{Average}(f) = 0.375, and

However, when we find f(x)\cdot g(x), we find that the product is everywhere zero! g(x) is zero for 0\le x\le 1, so f(x)\cdot g(x) is zero there, and g(x) is zero for 1\le x\le 2, so f(x)\cdot g(x) is zero there too. Thus the average value of the product is zero, and the average of the product is not equal to the product of the averages!

statement.p: If F'=f and F(0)=0, find F(b) for b=1, 2, 3, 4, 5, 6, and fill these values in the following table.

static.solution:
F(0)=0, F(b)=\int_0^{b} f(t)\,dt. For each b we determine F(b) graphically: for regions where f is constant, the integral over that region is just (length)(value of f); for regions that are triangular or trapezoidal, we calculate the area using either of \frac12(base)(height) (where the height is given by the value of f and may be negative), or (length)(average height). Thus,
F(0)=0
F(1)= F(0) + 1 = 0 + 1 = 1
F(2)= F(1) + 0.5 = 1 + 0.5 = 1.5
F(3)= F(2) - 0.5 = 1.5 - 0.5 = 1
F(4)= F(3) - 0.833333333333333 = 1 - 0.833333333333333 = 0.166666666666667
F(5)= F(4) - 0.5 = 0.166666666666667 - 0.5 = -0.333333333333333
and, finally,
F(6)= F(5) - 0.166666666666667 = -0.333333333333333 - 0.166666666666667 = -0.5.

and
Then find the value of the integral:

p.em: (Note that you can do this in two different ways!)

static.solution:
x=3, we are given that f(3)=0. Moving to the left on the interval 2 \lt x \lt 3, we have f'(x) = -2, and we can find f(2) by knowing that the change in f(x) over this interval is equal to the area under f'(x) between x=2 and x=3. Thus f(3) - f(2) = (-2)(1), so that f(2) = f(3) - (1)(-2) = 2. Similarly, continuing back to x=0, f(0) = f(2) - (2)(2) = -2
Moving to the right from x=3, we know that f'(x) = 3 on 3 \lt x \lt 5. So, as before, f(5) = f(3) + (2)(3) = 6. Similarly, continuing to x=7, f(7) = f(5) + (1)(-3) + (1)(1) = 4.
Then, the value of the integral \int_0^7 f'(x)\,dx is given by the sum \int_0^7 f'(x)\,dx = (2)(2) + (-2)(1) + (3)(2) + (-3)(1) + (1)(1) = 6.
Alternatively, knowing f(7)=4 and f(0)=-2 and using the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus, we have \int_0^7 f'(x)\,dx=f(7)-f(0) = (4) - (-2) = 6.

static.solution:
A,B. Since f' is everywhere positive, f is everywhere increasing. Hence the greatest value of f is at F and the least value of f is at A.
C,D. Directly from the graph, we see that f' is greatest at B and least at D.

li.p: A is an antiderivative of f
A is a derivative of f
A is a multiple of f

solution.p: a. We were given that A(x) = \int_1^x f(t) \, dt, so A(1) = \int_1^1 f(t) \, dt =0.
c. 4x-x^{2}-3 is a quadratic function.
d. The derivative of 4x-x^{2}-3 is 4-2x.
e. Thus, the derivative of A is f, or A'=f, so A is an antiderivative of f.

In Section 2.5, we learned the Chain Rule and how it can be applied to find the derivative of a composite function. In particular, if u is a differentiable function of x, and f is a differentiable function of u(x), then \frac{d}{dx} \left[ f(u(x)) \right] = f'(u(x)) \cdot u'(x). In words, we say that the derivative of a composite function c(x) = f(u(x)), where f is considered the "outer" function and u the "inner" function, is "the derivative of the outer function, evaluated at the inner function, times the derivative of the inner function."

(a) For each of the following functions, use the Chain Rule to find the function's derivative. Notice the label of each derivative respects the functions name (e.g., the derivative of g(x) should be labeled g'(x)).
(i) If g(x) = e^{3x}, then g'(x) =
(ii) If h(x) = \sin(5x+1), then h'(x) =
(iii) If p(x) = \arctan(2x), then p'(x) =
(iv) If q(x) = (2-7x)^4, then q'(x) =
(v) If r(x) = 3^{4-11x}, then r'(x) =

(b) For each of the following functions, use your work in (a) to help you determine the general antiderivative of the function. (Recall that the general antiderivative of a function includes +C to reflect the entire family of functions that share the same derivative.) Notice the label of each antiderivative respects the name (e.g., the antiderivative of m should be called M). Remember that you can check your work by computing the derivative of each proposed antiderivative.
(i) If m(x) = e^{3x}, then M(x) =
(ii) If n(x) = \cos(5x+1), then N(x) =
(iii) If \displaystyle s(x) = \frac{1}{1+4x^2}, then S(x) =
(iv) If v(x) = (2-7x)^3, then V(x) =
(v) If w(x) = 3^{4-11x}, then W(x) =
(c) Based on your experience in parts (a) and (b), conjecture an antiderivative for each of the following functions. Test your conjectures by computing the derivative of each proposed antiderivative.
(i) a(x) = \cos(\pi x), then A(x)=
(iii) c(x) = xe^{x^2}, then C(x)=

solution.p: a. (i) The derivative of g(x) = e^{3x} is g'(x) = 3e^{3x}\ln\!\left(e\right).
(ii) The derivative of h(x) = \sin(5x+1) is h'(x) = 5\cos\!\left(5x+1\right).
(iii) The derivative of p(x) = \arctan(2x) is p'(x) = 2\frac{1}{1+\left(2x\right)^{2}}.
(iv) The derivative of q(x) = (2-7x)^4 is q'(x) = -7\cdot 4\!\left(2-7x\right)^{3}.
(v) The derivative of r(x) = 3^{4-11x} is r'(x) = -11\ln\!\left(3\right)\cdot 3^{4-11x}.
b. (i) The general antiderivative of m(x) = e^{3x} is \frac{1}{3} e^{3x}, because the derivative of \frac{1}{3}e^{3x}+C is e^{3x}.
(ii) The general antiderivative of n(x) = \cos(5x+1) is \frac{1}{5}\sin\!\left(5x+1\right)+C, because the derivative of \frac{1}{5}\sin\!\left(5x+1\right)+C is n(x) = \cos(5x+1).
(iii) The general antiderivative of \displaystyle s(x) = \frac{1}{1+4x^2} is \frac{1}{2}\tan^{-1}\!\left(2x\right)+C.
(iv) The general antiderivative of v(x) = (2-7x)^3 is \frac{1}{-7\cdot 4} (2-7x)^4+C;
(v) The general antiderivative of w(x) = 3^{4-11x} is \frac{1}{\ln(3)\cdot(-11)} 3^{4-11x}+C;
(c) (i) The general antiderivative of a(x) = \cos(\pi x) is \frac{1}{\pi }\sin\!\left(\pi x\right)+C;
(ii) The general antiderivative of b(x) = (4x+7)^{11} is \frac{1}{4\cdot 12} (4x+7)^{12} +C;
(iii) The general antiderivative of c(x) = xe^{x^2} is \frac{1}{2}e^{x^{2}}+C;

statement.p: Solve the integral below with u-substitution. \int \frac{-3 \sec(2 x)\tan(2 x)}{\sec^{2}(2 x)} \, dx
Let u =
Then du =
Then, we substitute in the integral to get \displaystyle \int , (which has 'u' and 'du' in it, not 'x' or 'dx'. )
Now this is a basic integral. Evaluate it to get all possible antiderivatives in terms of 'u':
and then the final answer is \displaystyle \int \frac{-3 \sec(2 x)\tan(2 x)}{\sec^{2}(2 x)} \, dx \, =

hint.p: Remember that the derivative of \sec x is \sec x \tan x.
Let u = \sec\!\left(2x\right). Don't forget the chain rule when you find du.
Remember that to integrate something of the form \displaystyle \frac{1}{u^2} you should rewrite as u^{-2} and then use power rule.

solution.p: Let u=\sec\!\left(2x\right). Then we take the derivative of both sides to get du = 2\sec\!\left(2x\right)\tan\!\left(2x\right) \, dx

You can do the next step in different ways, but one way is to solve for dx. Since du = 2\sec\!\left(2x\right)\tan\!\left(2x\right) \, dx, we divide over to get that dx=\frac{1}{2\sec\!\left(2x\right)\tan\!\left(2x\right)} \, du Then we substitute back into the original integral. \int \frac{-3 \sec(2 x)\tan(2 x)}{\sec^{2}(2 x)} \, dx = \int \frac{-3 \sec(2 x)\tan(2 x)}{u^{2}} \frac{1}{2\sec\!\left(2x\right)\tan\!\left(2x\right)} \, du Which simplifies to \int -\frac{1.5}{u^{2}}du

Now, this is one of our basic integrals because we can write it as \displaystyle \int -1.5 u^{-2} \, du and thus we can integrate it. Constants in front just stay multiplied so we get \int -1.5 u^{-2} \, du = \frac{-1.5}{-1} u^{-1}+C Finally, make sure you put it back in terms of the original variable, which in this case is 'x'. So we substitute back in for 'u', which was \sec\!\left(2x\right). Thus the final answer to this integral is \int \frac{-3 \sec(2 x)\tan(2 x)}{\sec^{2}(2 x)} \, dx = 1.5\!\left(\sec\!\left(2x\right)\right)^{-1}+C

statement.p: Solve the integral below with u-substitution. \int 7 \csc^2(-3 x) e^{\cot(-3 x)} \, dx
Let u =
Then du =
Then, we substitute in the integral to get \displaystyle \int , (which has 'u' and 'du' in it, not 'x' or 'dx'. )
Now this is a basic integral. Evaluate it to get all possible antiderivatives in terms of 'u':
and then the final answer is \displaystyle \int 7 \csc^2(-3 x) e^{\cot(-3 x)} \, dx \, =

hint.p: Remember that the derivative of \cot x is -\csc^2(x)
Let u = \cot\!\left(-3x\right). Don't forget chain rule when you take the derivative.

solution.p: Let u=\cot\!\left(-3x\right). Then we take the derivative of both sides to get du = 3\csc^{2}\!\left(-3x\right) \, dx

You can do the next step in different ways, but one way is to solve for dx. Since du = 3\csc^{2}\!\left(-3x\right) \, dx, we divide over to get that dx=\frac{1}{3\csc^{2}\!\left(-3x\right)} \, du Then we substitute back into the original integral. \int 7 \csc^2(-3 x) e^{\cot(-3 x)} \, dx = \int 7 \csc^2(-3 x) e^{u} \frac{1}{3\csc^{2}\!\left(-3x\right)} \, du Which simplifies to \int 2.33333e^{u}du

Now, this is one of our basic integrals, and we can integrate it. Constants in front just stay multiplied so we get \int 2.33333e^{u}du = 2.33333e^{u}+C Finally, make sure you put it back in terms of the original variable, which in this case is 'x'. So we substitute back in for 'u', which was \cot\!\left(-3x\right). Thus the final answer to this integral is \int 7 \csc^2(-3 x) e^{\cot(-3 x)} \, dx = 2.33333e^{\cot\!\left(-3x\right)}+C

statement.p: Find the following integral. Note that you can check your answer by differentiation.
Find the the general antiderivative F(x) of the function f(x) given below. Note that you can check your answer by differentiation.
antiderivative F(x) =

static.solution: \int\,6 x^{3} \cos(x^{4})\,dx. We use substitution with w = x^{4} to find this. We have dw = 4\,x^{3}\,dx, so that \int\,6 x^{3} \cos(x^{4})\,dx = {3\over 2}\int\,\cos(w)\,dw = {3\over 2}\,\sin(w) + C = {3\over 2}\,\sin(x^{4}) + C.

statement.p: Find the following integral. Note that you can check your answer by differentiation.

static.solution: w = \ln(z). Then dw = \frac{1}{z}\,dz, so that \int\,\frac{\ln(z)^{5}}{z}\,dz = \int\,w^{5}\,dw = {1\over 6}\,w^{6} + C = {1\over 6}\,(\ln(z))^{6} + C.

statement.p: Find the following integral. Note that you can check your answer by differentiation.

static.solution: w = e^{4 x} + 9. Then dw = 4\,e^{4 x}\,dx, so that \int\,\frac{e^{4 x}}{9 + e^{4 x}}\,dx = {1\over 4}\int\,{1\over w}\,dw = {1\over 4}\,\ln(|w|) + C = {1\over 4}\,\ln(|e^{4 x} + 9|) + C. Because e^{4 x} + 9 is always positive, we can drop the absolute values from the argument of the natural log.

statement.p: Use the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus to find

static.solution: w = -\cos\!\left(q\right), so that dw = \sin\!\left(q\right)\,dq. Then w(3\pi) = 1 and w(3\pi/2) = 0, so that \int_{3\pi}^{3\pi/2}\, e^{-\cos\!\left(q\right)}\cdot \sin\!\left(q\right) \,dq = \int_1^0\,e^w\,dw = e^w\bigg|_1^0 = 1 - e.

statement.p: Consider the integral \displaystyle \int\,7\,x^{2}\,(x^{3} + 1)\,dx. In the following, we will evaluate the integral using two methods.
A. First, rewrite the integral by multiplying out the integrand:
Then evaluate the resulting integral term-by-term:
B. Next, rewrite the integral using the substitution w = x^{3} + 1:
Evaluate this integral (and back-substitute for w) to find the value of the original integral:
C. How are your expressions from parts (A) and (B) different? What is the difference between the two? (Ignore the constant of integration.)
(answer from B)-(answer from A) =
Are both of the answers correct? (Be sure you can explain why they are!)

static.solution:
A. \int\,7\,x^{2}\,(x^{3} + 1)\,dx = \int\,7\,x^{5} + 7\,x^{2}\,dx. Thus, antidifferentiating term-by-term, we get \int\,7\,x^{2}\,(x^{3} + 1)\,dx = {7\over6}\,x^{6} + {7\over3}\,x^{3} + C.
B. \int\,7\,x^{2}\,(x^{3} + 1)\,dx = \int\,{7\over3}\,w\,dw. Thus, antidifferentiating, we get \int\,7\,x^{2}\,(x^{3} + 1)\,dx = {7\over6}\,w^2 + C = {7\over6}\,(x^{3} + 1)^2 + C.
C. To see the difference between these two answers, we expand the second: (x^{3} + 1)^2 = x^{6} + 2\,x^{3} + 1, so the difference is ({7\over6} (x^{6} + 2\,x^{3} + 1)) - ({7\over6} \,x^{6} + {7\over3}\,x^{3}) = {7\over6}. That is, the difference is a constant! This is completely reasonable: the antiderivative is only determined up to a constant, and the arbitrary constant C that we get for the most general antiderivative will adjust for this difference.

statement.p: Evaluate the indefinite integral \int {10 (1+\tan(t))^5 \sec^2(t)}\, dt
Note: Any arbitrary constants used must be an upper-case "C".
Evaluate the integral \int {1 \cot(x) \ln(\sin(x))}\, dx
Note: Use an upper-case "C" for the constant of integration.

In Section 2.3, we developed the Product Rule and studied how it is employed to differentiate a product of two functions. In particular, recall that if f and g are differentiable functions of x, then \frac{d}{dx} \left[ f(x) \cdot g(x) \right] = f(x) \cdot g'(x) + g(x) \cdot f'(x).
(a) For each of the following functions, use the Product Rule to find the function's derivative. Be sure to label each derivative by name (e.g., the derivative of g(x) should be labeled g'(x)).
(i) If g(x) = x\sin(x), then g'(x) =
(ii) If h(x) = xe^x, then h'(x) =
(iii) If p(x) = x\ln(x), then p'(x) =
(iv.) If q(x) = x^2 \cos(x) , then q'(x) =
(v.) If r(x) = e^x \sin(x) , then r'(x) =
(b) Use your work in (a) to help you evaluate the following indefinite integrals. Use differentiation to check your work.
(i) \displaystyle \int xe^x + e^x \, dx =
(ii) \displaystyle \int e^x(\sin(x) + \cos(x)) \, dx =
(iii) \displaystyle \int 2x\cos(x) - x^2 \sin(x) \, dx -
(iv) \displaystyle \int x\cos(x) + \sin(x) \, dx =
(v) \displaystyle \int 1 + \ln(x) \, dx =

(c) Observe that the examples in (b) work nicely because of the derivatives you were asked to calculate in (a). Each integrand in (b) is precisely the result of differentiating one of the products of basic functions found in (a). To see what happens when an integrand is still a product but not necessarily the result of differentiating an elementary product, we consider how to evaluate \int x\cos(x) \, dx.

(i) First, observe that \frac{d}{dx} \left[ x\sin(x) \right] = x\cos(x) + \sin(x). Integrating both sides indefinitely and using the fact that the integral of a sum is the sum of the integrals, we find that \int \left(\frac{d}{dx} \left[ x\sin(x) \right] \right) \, dx = \int x\cos(x) \, dx + \int \sin(x) \, dx. In this last equation, evaluate the indefinite integral on the left side.
In that same equation, now evaluate the indefinite integral all the way to the right side.
(ii) Using your answers to the previous two parts, solve the resulting equation for the expression \int x \cos(x) \, dx.
Calculate the following integral: \int x \cos(4 x) \, dx
We let u= and dv =
So \ \ \ du= and v =
and then use the integration-by-parts formula to find that
\displaystyle \int x \cos( 4 x) \, dx = - \displaystyle \int
and finally, we finish evaluating to get that \displaystyle \int x \cos( 4 x) dx =

hint.p: We pick u and dv so that dv can be integrated, while ideally, u gets simpler.
Both x and \cos\!\left(4x\right) can be integrated, so we can choose for u to get simpler.

The derivative of x is 1 (which is of lower degree) while the derivative of \cos\!\left(4x\right) is -4 \sin(4 x), (which is another trig function and not any simpler). Thus, we should let u=x and dv=\cos\!\left(4x\right)dx.
Then du=dx and v=\frac{1}{4} \sin( 4 x).

Next, remember that the integration by parts formula says that \int u \, dv = u\cdot v - \int v \, du So, substituting in what we already know are u, \ v,\ du and dv, we get that \int x \cos(4 x) \, dx = x \cdot \frac{1}{4}\sin(4 x) - \int \frac{1}{4}\sin(4 x) \, dx
Lastly, we integrate the second part, so the answer is \int x \cos(4 x) \, dx = \frac{1}{4} x \sin(4 x) + \frac{1}{16}\cos(4 x)+C

solution.p: Let u=x and dv=\cos\!\left(4x\right)dx.
Then du=dx and v=\frac{1}{4} \sin(4 x).

The integration by parts formula says that \int u \, dv = u\cdot v - \int v \, du So, substituting in, we get that \int x \cos(4 x) \, dx = x \cdot \frac{1}{4}\sin(4 x - \int \frac{1}{4}\sin(4 x) \cdot dx Lastly, we integrate the second part, so the answer is \int x \cos(4 x) \, dx = \frac{1}{4} x \sin(4 x) + \frac{1}{16}\cos(4 x)+C

statement.p: Calculate the following integral: \int x \sec^{2}\!\left(5x\right) \, dx
We let u= and dv =
So \ \ \ du= and v =
and then use the integration-by-parts formula to find that
\displaystyle \int \sec^{2}\!\left(5x\right) x \, dx = - \displaystyle \int
and finally, we finish evaluating to get that \displaystyle \int \sec^{2}\!\left(5x\right) x \, dx =

hint.p: We pick u and dv so that dv can be integrated, and then (ideally) u gets simpler.
Both x and \sec^{2}\!\left(5x\right) can be easily integrated, so pick them so that u gets simpler.
Let u=x so du= dx.
Then dv =\sec^{2}\!\left(5x\right)dx, and we integrate to get that v= \frac{1}{5} \tan(5 x)
Remember that even though it's not Basic, you do know how to integrate \tan(5 x). It's number 7 on the u-Substitution practice worksheet we did in class.

solution.p: Let u=x and dv=\sec^{2}\!\left(5x\right)dx.
Then du=dx and v=\frac{1}{5} \tan(5 x).

The integration by parts formula says that \int u \, dv = u\cdot v - \int v \, du So, substituting in, we get that \int x \sec^{2}\!\left(5x\right) \, dx = x \cdot \frac{1}{5} \tan(5 x) - \int \frac{1}{5} \tan(5 x) \, dx =\frac{1}{5} x \tan(5 x) - \int \frac{1}{5} \tan(5 x) \, dx Unfortunately, the integral is not Basic, but we can rewrite it and integrate it using u-substitution. \frac{1}{5} x \tan(5 x) - \int \frac{1}{5} \frac{\sin(5 x)}{\cos(5 x)} \, dx Let u=\cos(5 x) so du = -5 \sin(5 x) \, dx and solving for dx gives us dx=\frac{du}{-5 \sin(5 x)}.

Substituting back into the integral gives us: \int \frac{1}{5} \frac{\sin(5 x)}{\cos(5 x)} \, dx = \int \frac{1}{5} \frac{\sin(5 x)}{u} \, \frac{du}{-5 \sin(5 x)} = \int \frac{-1}{25} \frac{du}{u} This integrates to \frac{-1}{25} \ln(u) and substituting back in for u gives \frac{-1}{25} \ln(\cos(5 x))+C Combining it with the non-integrated term from integration by parts, we get the final answer: \int x \sec^{2}\!\left(5x\right) \, dx = \frac{1}{5} x \tan(5 x) - \frac{-1}{25} \ln(\cos(5 x))+C

statement.p: Calculate the following integral: \int x^{8} \ln\!\left(-6x\right) \, dx
We let u= and dv =
So \ \ \ du= and v =
and then use the integration-by-parts formula to find that
\displaystyle \int x^{8} \ln\!\left(-6x\right) \, dx = - \displaystyle \int
and finally, we finish evaluating to get that \displaystyle \int x^{8} \ln\!\left(-6x\right) \, dx =

hint.p: We pick u and dv so that dv can be integrated, and then (ideally) u gets simpler.
We do not know how to easily integrate \ln\!\left(-6x\right), so that must be u.
Then everything else in the integral must equal dv. So dv =x^{8}dx.
Since u=\ln\!\left(-6x\right) we take the derivative to get that du= \frac{1}{x}dx =\frac{1}{x} \, dx.
Since dv =x^{8}dx we integrate to get that v= \frac{1}{9} x^{9}

Next, remember that the integration by parts formula says that \int u \, dv = u\cdot v - \int v \, du So, substituting in what we already know are u, \ v,\ du and dv, we get that \int x^{8} \ln\!\left(-6x\right) \, dx = \ln\!\left(-6x\right) \cdot \frac{1}{9} x^{9} - \int \frac{1}{9} x^{9} \cdot \frac{1}{x} \, dx Now cancel the x's in that last integral, and it's a basic integral (power rule) so you can evaluate it.

solution.p: Let u=\ln\!\left(-6x\right) and dv=x^{8}dx.
Then du=\frac{1}{x}dx and v=\frac{1}{9} x^{9}.

The integration by parts formula says that \int u \, dv = u\cdot v - \int v \, du So, substituting in, we get that \int x^8 \ln(-6 x) \, dx = \ln\!\left(-6x\right) \cdot \frac{1}{9}x^{9} - \int \frac{1}{9}x^{9} \cdot \frac{1}{x} \, dx =\ln\!\left(-6x\right) \cdot \frac{1}{9}x^{9} - \int \frac{1}{9}x^{8} \, dx Lastly, we integrate the second part, so the answer is \int x^8 \ln(-6 x) \, dx = \frac{1}{9}x^{9} \cdot \ln\!\left(-6x\right) - \frac{1}{81}x^{9}+C

statement.p: Use integration by parts to evaluate the integral.
If g(1)=-3, g(5)=5, and \displaystyle \int_1^5 \! g(x) \, dx = -7, evaluate the integral \displaystyle \int_1^5 \! x g'(x)\, dx.
Answer:

solution.p: SOLUTION

Let u = x, \; dv = g'(x) \, dx \; \Rightarrow \; du = dx, \; v = g(x). We then have \int_1^5 \! x g'(x)\, dx = \Big[x g(x)\Big]_1^5 - \int_1^5 g(x) \, dx = \Big[ 5\cdot g(5) - 1 \cdot g(1) \Big] + 7 = 5\cdot (5) + 3 + 7 = 35

1. For \int\,x\sin x\,dx, integration by parts is appropriate, because by taking u = x and v' = \sin(x), we end up with an integral that is easy to find.
2. For \int\,{x\over 1 + x^{2}}\,dx, substitution is appropriate, because by taking w=1 + x^{2} we get an integral we can find.

statement.p: Calculate the integral below by partial fractions and by using the indicated substitution. Be sure that you can show how the results you obtain are the same. \int \frac{2x}{x^{2}-25}\,dx
First, rewrite this with partial fractions:
\int \frac{2x}{x^{2}-25}\,dx = \int dx + \int dx = + + C.

p.em: (Note that you should not include the +C in your entered answer, as it has been provided at the end of the expression.)

statement.p: Next, use the substitution w = x^2 - 25 to find the integral:
\int \frac{2x}{x^{2}-25}\,dx = \int dw = + C = + C.

p.em: (For the second answer blank, give your antiderivative in terms of the variable w. Again, note that you should not include the +C in your answer.)

static.solution:
\frac{2x}{x^2-25}=\frac{A}{x+5}+\frac{B}{x-5} so that 2x = A(x-5)+B(x+5) = (A+B)x + 5 (-A+B). Solving, we get A=B=1, so that \int \frac{2x}{x^2-25}\,dx= \int \left(\frac{1}{x+5}+\frac{1}{x-5}\right)\,dx =\ln|x+5|+\ln|x-5|+C.
Using the substitution w=x^2-25, we get dw= 2x\,dx, so we have \int \frac{2x}{x^2-25}\,dx= \int \frac{dw}{w}=\ln|w|+C = \ln|x^2-25|+C.
The properties of logarithms show that the two results are the same: \ln|x+5|+\ln|x-5| = \ln|(x+5)(x-5)| =\ln|x^2-25|.

statement.p: Calculate the integral:

static.solution: \frac{1}{(x+6)(x+8)}=\frac{A}{x+6}+\frac{B}{x+8}, giving 1 = A(x+8)+B(x+6), or 1 = (A+B)x+ (8 A+6 B). Solving for A and B, we find A = 0.5 and B = -0.5, so \int \frac{1}{(x+6)(x+8)}\,dx= \int\frac{0.5}{x+6}\,dx + \int \frac{-0.5}{x+8}\,dx = 0.5\ln\!\left(\left|x+6\right|\right)-0.5\ln\!\left(\left|x+8\right|\right)+C.

statement.p: Calculate the integral

static.solution: \frac{7 x + 1}{x^2-3x+2} = \frac{7 x+1}{(x-1)(x-2)} = \frac{A}{x-1} + \frac{B}{x-2}. Multiplying by (x-1) and (x-2), this becomes 7 x+1 = A(x-2)+B(x-1), or A+B = 7 \quad\hbox{and}\quad -2A - B = 1. Solving this system yields A = -8 and B = 15. Then \int\frac{7 x+1}{x^2-3x+2}dx = \int\left(\frac{15}{x-2} - \frac{8}{x-1}\right)\,dx = 15\ln\!\left(\left|x-2\right|\right)-8\ln\!\left(\left|x-1\right|\right)+C.

statement.p: Consider the following indefinite integral. \int \frac{5 x^3+ 10 x^2+ 64 x+ 96 }{x^4+16 x^2}\, dx
The integrand has partial fractions decomposition:
\frac{a}{x^2} + \frac{b}{x} + \frac{cx + d}{x^2+16} where
Now integrate term by term to evaluate the integral.
Answer: +C
The form of the partial fraction decomposition of a rational function is given below.
Now evaluate the indefinite integral.

solution.p: SOLUTION

Multiplying by the least common denominator gives 3x^{2}-10x+4 = A(x^2+4)+(Bx+C)(x - 5) Rearranging terms on the right hand side, yields 3x^{2}-10x+4 = (A+B)x^2+(-5B+C)x + 4 A - 5C Now we equate the coefficients: \begin{array}{rl} A+B \amp = 3 \\ -5B +C \amp = -10 \\ 4 A - 5C \amp = 4 \end{array} Solving the system gives A=1, \; B = 2 and C= 0 so the partial fraction decomposition is \frac{3x^{2}-10x+4}{(x - 5)(x^2+4)} = \frac{1}{x - 5} + \frac{2x}{x^2+4} The definite integral is then \displaystyle \int \frac{3x^{2}-10x+4}{(x - 5)(x^2+4)} dx = \ln\!\left(\left|x-5\right|\right) + 1\ln\!\left(x^{2}+4\right) +C

statement.p: As we begin to investigate ways to approximate definite integrals, it will be insightful to compare results to integrals whose exact values we know. To that end, the following sequence of questions centers on \int_0^3 x^2 \, dx.

(a) Use the Desmos graph at https://www.desmos.com/calculator/jnhujcwbie (The link opens a new tab/window) with the function f(x) = x^2 on the window of x values from 0 to 3 to compute L_3, the left Riemann sum with three subintervals.
(b) Likewise, use the same Desmos graph to compute R_3 and M_3, the right and middle Riemann sums with three subintervals, respectively.
(c) Use the Fundamental Theorem of Calculus to compute the exact value of I = \int_0^3 x^2 \, dx.

(d) We define the error in an approximation of a definite integral to be the difference between the integral's exact value (I and the approximation's value. What is the error that results from using L_3? From R_3? From M_3?

(e) In what follows in this section, we will learn a new approach to estimating the value of a definite integral known as the Trapezoid Rule. The basic idea is to use trapezoids, rather than rectangles, to estimate the area under a curve. What is the formula for the area of a trapezoid with bases of length b_1 and b_2 and height h? (Type b1 and b2 for the bases).
(f) Working by hand, estimate the area under f(x) = x^2 on [0,3] using three subintervals and three corresponding trapezoids.
What is the error in this approximation? I - T_3=
How does it compare to the errors you calculated in (d)? Select all answers that are true.

Smaller in magnitude than L_3 error and R_3 error, but more than M_3 error
2 times the magnitude as compared with M_3 error
More in magnitude than R_3 error
Opposite sign compared with M_3 error

statement.p: (a) What is the exact value of \int_{0}^{4}\,e^x\,dx?
Find LEFT(2), RIGHT(2), TRAP(2), MID(2), and SIMP(2); compute the error for each.
Repeat part (b) with n=4 (instead of n=2).
For each rule in part (b), as n goes from n=2 to n=4, does the error go down approximately as you would expect? Explain by calculating the ratios of the errors:
Error LEFT(2)/Error LEFT(4) =
Error RIGHT(2)/Error RIGHT(4) =
Error TRAP(2)/Error TRAP(4) =
Error MID(2)/Error MID(4) =
Error SIMP(2)/Error SIMP(4) =

p.em: (Be sure that you can explain in words why these do (or don't) make sense.)

static.solution:
(a) \int_{0}^{4}\,e^x\,dx = e^x\bigg|_{0}^{4} = e^4 - e^0 \approx 53.5982\ldots
(b) Computing the sums directly, since \Delta x=2, we have
LEFT(2) = 2\cdot e^0 + 2\cdot e^{2} \approx 16.7782
RIGHT(2) = 2\cdot e^{2} + 2\cdot e^{4} \approx 123.974
TRAP(2) = \frac 1 2 ( 16.7782 + 123.974 ) \approx 70.3763
MID(2) = 2\cdot e^{1} + 2\cdot e^{3\cdot 1} \approx 45.6077
and SIMP(2) = (2 MID(2) + TRAP(2))/3 \approx 53.8638.
And the errors are just the actual value minus the approximate values, or
error(LEFT(2)) = 36.8201; error(RIGHT(2)) = -70.3758; error(TRAP(2)) = -16.7782; error(MID(2)) = 7.9906; and error(SIMP(2)) = -0.2656.
(c) Similarly, since \Delta x = 0.5, we have
LEFT(4) = 31.1929; error = 22.4053
RIGHT(4) = 84.7911; error = -31.1928
TRAP(4) = 57.992; error = -4.3937
MID(4) = 51.4284; error = 2.1698

statement.p: Find the area of the shaded region below.
Area =
Find the area between y = 3 \sin x and y = 9 \cos x over the interval \left[0,\pi\right]. Sketch the curves if necessary.

static.solution:
Over the interval [0,\pi], the graphs y = 3\sin x and y = 9 \cos x intersect when 3\sin x = 9 \cos x, i.e., \tan x = \frac{9}{3}, i.e., x=\tan^{-1}(\frac{9}{3})=1.24904577239825.
Let t = \tan^{-1}(\frac{9}{3}).
Over the interval \left[0, t\right], the graph of y = 3\sin x lies below that of y = 9 \cos x. Hence, the area between the two curves is \int_0^{ t}(9 \cos x-3 \sin x)dx \begin{array}{ll} \amp =\left.(9\sin x+3\cos x)\right|_0^{ t} \cr \amp =\left(9\sin t+3\cos t\right)-(9\cdot 0+3\cdot 1)\cr \amp =\left(9\sin t+3\cos t\right)-3 \end{array}
Since t = \tan^{-1}(\frac{9}{3}), we have \tan t = \frac{9}{3}. Considering a rightangle triangle with an angle which opposite side has length 9 and adjacent side has length 3, we see that the hypotenues is \sqrt{90}. Thus \sin t = \frac{9}{\sqrt{90}} and \cos t = \frac{3}{\sqrt{90}}.
9\sin t+3\cos t = \frac{9^2}{\sqrt{90}} + \frac{3^2}{\sqrt{90}} = \frac{9^2+3^2}{\sqrt{90}} = \frac{90}{\sqrt{90}}=\sqrt{90}.
Thus, \int_0^{ t}(9 \cos x-3 \sin x)dx= \sqrt{90}-3.
Over the interval \left[ t,\pi\right], the graph of y = 3\sin x lies above that of y = 9 \cos x. Hence, the area between the two curves is \int^\pi_{ t}(3\sin x - 9 \cos x)dx \begin{array}{ll} \amp =-\left.(9\sin x+3\cos x)\right|^\pi_{ t} \cr \amp =3 + \sqrt{90} \end{array}
Thus the total area is the sum of the above two integrals, which is 2\sqrt{90}.

statement.p: Find the area of the region between the curves 4x+y^2=12 and x=y.
These two curves intersect when y = and y = .
This is better to integrate with respect to y, since we know the starting value and ending value of y, and the region can be described with one integral,
where c = , d = and
Then we find that the area is .

solution.p: Looking at a graph of the region, y starts at c=-6 and ends at d=2, and x goes from the line x=y on the left side of the region to the graph of the sideways parabola 4x+y^2=12 on the right. But that has x in it, so we solve for x and get x=\frac{12-y^2}{4}. So the integral is \displaystyle \int_{-6}^2 \frac{12-y^2}{4}-y \ dy

Now we can simplify and integrate, \displaystyle \int_{-6}^2 \frac{12-y^2}{4}-y \ dy =\int_{-6}^2 \left[ 3-\frac{1}{4}y^2-y \right] \ dy = 3y- \frac{1}{12}y^3-\frac{1}{2}y^2 \biggr|_{-6}^2 =6-\frac{8}{12}-\frac{4}{2}-\left( -18+\frac{6^3}{12}-\frac{36}{2} \right) = \frac{64}{3}=21.3333

Approximate the arc length of the curve y=\frac{1}{4}x^4 over the interval [1,2] using the trapezoidal rule and 8 intervals (i.e., T_{8}).

solution.p: Since y=\frac14x^4, 1+(y')^2=1+(x^3)^2=1+x^6 Therefore \sqrt{1+y'^2}=\sqrt{1+x^6} and the arc length over [1,2] is: \int_1^2\sqrt{1+x^6}dx

Let f(x)=\sqrt{1+x^6}. We take the estimate of the integral using the Trapezoidal Rule with 8 subdivisions. Since n=8, \Delta x=\frac{2-1}{8} x_i=1+i\Delta x\:(i=0,\ldots,8) y_i=f(1+i\Delta x) T_{8}=\sum_{i=0}^{7}\frac12(y_i+y_{i+1})\Delta x
From this, T_{8} is \frac{1}{16} of the sum of the last column in the above table.

Find the volume of the solid obtained by rotating the region in the first quadrant bounded by y=x^{6}, y=1, and the y-axis around the y-axis.
Volume =

static.solution: \Delta y and radius x=\root 6\of{y}. Thus \hbox{Volume of slice }\approx \pi x^2\Delta y =\pi y^{1/3}\,\Delta y, and \hbox{Volume of solid } = \lim_{\Delta y\to 0}\Sigma\pi y^{1/3}\,\Delta y = \int_0^1 \pi y^{1/3}\, dy = {3 \pi\over 4} y^{1 + 1/3}\bigg|_0^1 = {3 \pi\over 4}.

statement.p: Find the volume of the solid obtained by rotating the region in the first quadrant bounded by y=x^{6}, y=1, and the y-axis around the x-axis.
Volume =

static.solution: \Delta x, outer radius y=1 and inner radius y=x^{6}. Therefore, \hbox{Volume of slice }\approx \pi 1^2\Delta x-\pi y^2\Delta x = \pi(1-x^{12})\, \Delta x. Therefore, \hbox{Volume of solid } = \lim_{\Delta x\to0} \Sigma \pi(1-x^{12})\,\Delta x = \int_0^1\pi(1-x^{12})\, dx =\pi\left(x-\frac{x^{13}}{13}\right)\Bigg|_0^1 = \pi(1 - {1\over 13}) = {12\over13} \pi.

statement.p: Find the volume of the solid obtained by rotating the region in the first quadrant bounded by y=x^{6}, y=1, and the y-axis about the line y=-5.
Volume =

static.solution: y=-5. We slice it into rings vertically. A typical ring has thickness \Delta x, outer radius 1+5=6, and inner radius y+5=x^{6}+5. Thus \hbox{Volume of slice }\approx \pi 6^2\Delta x - \pi(x^{6}+5)^2\Delta x = \pi(11 - x^{12} - 10 x^{6})\, \Delta x. Therefore, we have \hbox{Volume of solid } = \int_0^1\pi(11 - x^{12} - 10 x^{6})\,dx = \pi \left(11 x - \frac{x^{13}}{13} - {10\over 7} x^{7}\right)\Bigg|_0^1 = \pi ( 11 - {1\over 13} - {10\over 7} ).

A rod has length 5 meters. At a distance x meters from its left end, the density of the rod is given by \delta(x)=5 + 6 x g/m.
(a) Complete the Riemann sum for the total mass of the rod (use Dx in place of \Delta x):
mass = \Sigma
(b) Convert the Riemann sum to an integral and find the exact mass.
mass =
(include units)

static.solution:
(a) Suppose we choose an x, 0\leq x\leq 5. If \Delta x is a small fraction of a meter, then the density of the rod is approximately \delta(x) anywhere from x to x+\Delta x meters from the left end of the rod. The mass of the rod from x to x+\Delta x meters is therefore approximately \delta(x) \Delta x = (5 + 6 x)\Delta x. If we slice the rod into N pieces, then a Riemann sum is \Sigma_{i=1}^{N}(5 + 6 x_i)\Delta x, or, more loosely, \Sigma (5 + 6 x)\Delta x.
(b) The definite integral is M=\int_0^{5} \delta(x)\,dx = \int_0^{5} (5 + 6 x)\,dx= (5 x + 3 x^2)\bigg|_0^{5} = 100 \hbox{ grams}.

static.solution:

The center of mass is \overline x = \frac{\int_0^\pi\,x(8+\sin\!\left(x\right))\,dx}{27.1327} = \frac{\pi}2.

statement.p: Suppose that the density of cars (in cars per mile) down a 20-mile stretch of the Pennsylvania Turnpike is approximated by \delta(x) = 250 \left(2+\sin\left(4\sqrt{x + 0.2}\right)\right), at a distance x miles from the Breezewood toll plaza. Sketch a graph of this function for 0\leq x\leq 20.
(a) Complete the Riemann sum that approximates the total number of cars on this 20-mile stretch (use Dx instead of \Delta x):
Number = \Sigma
(b) Find the total number of cars on the 20-mile stretch.
Number =

static.solution:
(a) Suppose we choose an x, 0\le x\le 20. We approximate the density of the number of the cars between x and x+\Delta x miles as \delta(x) cars per mile. Therefore, the number of cars between x and x+\Delta x is approximately \delta(x)\Delta x. If we slice the 20 mile strip into N slices, we get that the total number of cars is C \approx \Sigma_{i=1}^N \delta(x_i)\Delta x = \Sigma_{i=1}^N \left[ 500 + 250\sin(4\sqrt{x_i + 0.2})\right]\Delta x, where \Delta x =20/N. This is a right-hand approximation; the corresponding left-hand approximation is \Sigma_{i=0}^{N-1}\delta(x_i)\Delta x. We can more loosely write both approximations without referring to the number of steps as C \approx \Sigma \left[ 500 + 250\sin(4\sqrt{x + 0.2})\right]\Delta x.
(b) As N\to\infty, the Riemann sum above approaches the integral C =\int_0^{20} (500 + 250\sin4\sqrt{x + 0.2})\,dx. If we calculate the integral numerically, we find C\approx 9571.98. We can also find the integral exactly as follows: C = \int_0^{20} (500 + 250\sin4\sqrt{x +0.2})\,dx = \int_0^{20} 500\,dx +\int_0^{20} 250\sin4\sqrt{x + 0.2}\,dx = 10000 + 250\int_0^{20}\sin4\sqrt{x +0.2}\,dx. Let w = \sqrt{x +0.2}, so x =w^2 -0.2 and dx =2w\,dw. Then \int_{x=0}^{x=20}\sin 4\sqrt{x +0.2}\,dx = 2\int_{w=\sqrt{0.2}}^{w=\sqrt{20.2}} w\sin 4w\,dw, = 2\left[-{1\over 4}w\cos 4w +{1\over 16}\sin 4w\right] \bigg|_{\sqrt{0.2}}^{\sqrt{20.2}} \approx -1.597. (To find the integral we used the appropriate entry in a table of integrals.) Using this, we have C\approx 10000 + 250(-1.597) \approx 9571.98, which matches our numerical approximation.

A tank in the shape of an inverted right circular cone has height 6 meters and radius 4 meters. It is filled with 5 meters of hot chocolate. Find the work required to empty the tank by pumping the hot chocolate over the top of the tank. The density of hot chocolate is \delta = 1030 \ \textrm{kg}/\textrm{m}^3. Your answer must include the correct units.
Work =

solution.p: SOLUTION

We think of the tank as made from infinitely many 'infinitesimal' horizontal slices, with x the vertical distance an infinitesimal slice of the water is from the bottom of the tank (the vertex of the right circular cone).
A cross section through the vertical center to the side is approximated below (not necessarily to scale).

Now the large right triangle with height 6 and top side length 4 is similar to the right triangle with height x and top side length r. So \frac{6}{4} = \frac{x}{r}\implies 6 r = 4 x or r = {\frac{2}{3}} x.
Therefore the area of every infinitesimal slice is A(x) = \pi(r)^2=\pi({\frac{2}{3}} x)^2={\frac{4}{9}} \pi x^2 \text{meter}^2.

The infinitesimal slice has volume dV=A(x)dx = {\frac{4}{9}} \pi x^2\,dx \text{meter}^3, and since mass = density\times volume, the mass of our infinitesimal slice is dm = \delta dV where \delta= 1030 \frac{kg}{\text{meter}^3}.
So the mass of the slice at x is \delta\,dV= (1030)\left({\frac{4}{9}} \pi x^2\right)\,dx kg. We now must find mgh for each slice.
Each slice at x must be lifted a height h = (6-x) meters, and g=9.8 \frac{meters}{sec^2} . So mgh for each slice is 9.8(1030)\left({\frac{4}{9}} \pi x^2\right)(6-x)\,dx Joules.

statement.p: A fuel oil tank is an upright cylinder, buried so that its circular top is 12 feet beneath ground level. The tank has a radius of 6 feet and is 18 feet high, although the current oil level is only 14 feet deep. Calculate the work required to pump all of the oil to the surface. Oil weighs 50\, \hbox{lb/ft}^3.
Work =
(include units)

static.solution:
h below the surface with thickness \Delta h. We can then calculate the volume of the slab and the work needed to raise this slab to the surface, a distance of h. \hbox{Volume of slab } = \pi r^2\Delta h = 36 \pi \Delta h
\hbox{Distance to raise } = h
\hbox{Work to raise } = (36 \pi)(50)(h) \Delta h.
Integrating the work over all such slabs, we have \hbox{Work} = \int_{16}^{30} (50)(36\pi)(h) \,dh = 900\pi h^2{\bigg|}_{16}^{30} = 579600 \pi \hbox{ lbf}.

statement.p: A rectangular swimming pool 50 ft long, 10 ft wide, and 16 ft deep is filled with water to a depth of 14 ft. Use an integral to find the work required to pump all the water out over the top. (Take as the density of water \delta = 62.4 \hbox{lb/ft}^3.)
Work =
(include units)

static.solution:
h ft above the bottom, a slice of thickness \Delta h has \hbox{Volume }\approx 50\cdot 10\Delta h \hbox{ ft}{}^3. Since the density of water is \rho lb/ft{}^3, \hbox{Weight of the slice }\approx\rho(50 \cdot 10 \cdot \Delta h) \hbox{ lbs}. The distance to lift the slice of water at height h ft is 16 - h ft, so the work to move one slice, \Delta W, is \Delta W = \rho \cdot \hbox{Volume} \cdot \hbox{Distance lifted} \approx \rho(50 \cdot 10 \cdot \Delta h)(16 - h) = 500 \rho (16 - h) \Delta h\hbox{ ft-lb}.
The work done, W, to pump all the water is the sum of the work done on the pieces: W \approx \Sigma\, 500 \rho(16-h)\Delta h. As \Delta h \rightarrow 0, we obtain a definite integral. Since h varies from h = 0 to h = 14 and \rho=62.4\hbox{ lb/ft}{}^3, the total work is: W = \int_0^{14} 31200 (16-h)dh = 31200 \left(16 h - {h^2\over 2}\right)\bigg|_0^{14} = 31200 (126) = 3931200\, \hbox{lbf}.

statement.p: Water in a cylinder of height 11 ft and radius 2 ft is to be pumped out. The density of water is 62.4 lb/ft{}^3. Find the work required if
(a) The tank is full of water and the water is to be pumped over the top of the tank.
Work =
(include units)
(b) The tank is full of water and the water must be pumped to a height 7 ft above the top of the tank.
Work =
(include units)
(c) The depth of water in the tank is 7 ft and the water must be pumped over the top of the tank.
Work =
(include units)

static.solution:
(a) We slice the water horizontally. Each slice is a cylindrical slab of radius and thickness \Delta h, so
\hbox{Volume of each slab }\approx \pi 2^2 \Delta h\hbox{ ft}^3. The density of water is \delta = 62.4 lb/ft{}^3, so \hbox{Weight of slab }\approx \delta\pi2^2 \Delta h \hbox{ lb.} Water at a height of h ft must be lifted a distance of 11 - h ft. \hbox{ Work to move one slice} =\delta \cdot \hbox{Volume} \cdot \hbox{Distance lifted} \approx \delta (\pi (2)^2 \Delta h)(11 - h)\hbox{ ft-lb.} Plugging in \delta=62.4 and since h varies from h = 0 to h = 11, the total work, W, is: W = \int_0^{11}{\delta(\pi 2^2 )(11-h)dh} = 2^2\delta \pi \int_0^{11}{(11 - h)dh} = (2^2) 62.4 \pi\left(11 h-\frac{h^2}2\right) \Bigg|_0^{11} = 47440.6\ {\rm lbf}. The total work required is 47440.6\ {\rm lbf}.
(b) This is the same as part (a) except the water must be lifted a distance of 18 - h ft. The total work is: W = \int_0^{11}{\delta(\pi 2^2 )(7-h)dh} = 2^2\delta \pi \int_0^{11}{(18 - h)dh} = (2^2) 62.4 \pi \left(18 h-\frac{h^2}2\right)\Bigg|_0^{11} = 107819\ {\rm lbf}. The total work required is 107819\ {\rm lbf}.
(c) This is the same as part (a) except that h varies from h=0 to h=7. The total work is: W = \int_0^{7}{\delta(\pi 2^2 )(11-h)dh} = 2^2\delta \pi \int_0^{7}{(11 -h)dh} = (2^2) 62.4 \pi \left(11 h-\frac{h^2}2\right)\Bigg|_0^{11} = 41167.4\ {\rm lbf}. The total work required is 41167.4\ {\rm lbf}.

statement.p: Calculate the integral below, if it converges. If it does not converge, enter diverges for your answer.

static.solution: \int_{0}^{\infty} 4xe^{-x^{2}} dx = \lim_{b \rightarrow \infty} \int_{0}^b 4xe^{-x^{2}} dx = \left.\lim_{b \rightarrow \infty} \left({{-4} \over 2} e^{-x^2}\right) \right|_0^b = \lim_{b \rightarrow \infty} \left({{-4} \over 2} e^{-b^2} - {{-4} \over 2} e^{-0^2}\right) = 0 + {4\over 2} e^{-0} = {4\over 2} . This integral converges to {4\over 2}.

statement.p: Calculate the integral, if it converges. If it diverges, enter diverges for your answer.

static.solution: w = 1 + e^{2 x}, we have \int_{-\infty}^{0}\,{e^{2 x}\over 1 + e^{2 x}}\,dx = \lim\limits_{b\to 1^{+}} \int_b^{1 + e^{0}} {1\over 2}{dw\over w} = \lim\limits_{b\to 1^{+}} {1\over 2}(\ln(1 + e^{0}) - \ln(b)) = {1\over 2}\ln(1 + e^{0}).

statement.p: Calculate the integral, if it converges. If it diverges, enter diverges for your answer.

static.solution: 1/v is undefined at v=0. To evaluate it, we must split the region of integration up into two pieces, from 0 to 3 and from -3 to 0. But notice, \int_0^{3}{1\over v}\, dv = \lim_{b\to 0^+}\int_b^{3} {1\over v}\, dv = \lim_{b\to 0^+}\left({\ln v}\bigg|_b^{3}\right) = \ln(3) - \ln b. As b\to 0^+, this goes to infinity and the integral diverges, so our original integral also diverges.

statement.p: Find the area under the curve y = \tan(t) between t = 0 and t = \pi/2. Enter diverges if the area is not bounded.
area =

static.solution:
\int_0^{\pi/2}\,\tan(t)\,dt. However, the integrand is undefined at t = \pi/2, so this is an improper integral. We find \int_0^{\pi/2}\,\tan(t)\,dt = \lim\limits_{a\to\pi/2^{-}}\,\int_0^a\,\tan(t)\,dt = \lim\limits_{a\to\pi/2^{-}}\,(-\ln|\cos(t)|)\bigg|_0^a = \lim\limits_{a\to\pi/2^{-}}( -\ln|\cos(a)| + \ln(1) ). However, -\ln|\cos(a)| is undefined as a\to\pi/2, so this integral diverges.
Thus, because the integral diverges, the area is not bounded.

The position of an object moving along a line is given by the function s(t), where s is measured in feet and t in seconds. We determine that the velocity is v(t) = 4t + 1 feet per second.
How much does the position change over the time interval [0,4]?
Change in position = feet

If you are told instead that the object's initial position is s(0) = 3, what is s(2)?

Select all that apply.
If, in addition to knowing the velocity function is v(t) = 4t+1, we know the initial position s(0), how many possibilities are there for s(t)?

static.solution: \int_0^4 4t+1 \, dt = 36 feet. Therefore, the position function will be s_0+ 2t^2+t, where s_0 is the initial velocity.

statement.p: Match the graphs below with the following descriptions by indicating the graph corresponding to each description in the answer blank to the left of the description. (Note that because this is a matching question, it does not show which parts are incorrect.)

li.p: The speed of a car traveling at uniform speed and then braking uniformly.
The temperature of a metal ingot placed in a furnace and then removed.
The mass of Carbon-14 in a historical specimin.
The number of bacteria on a nutrient petri dish after a group of bacteria is initially introduced.
The cost of a product in an economy suffering from a constant inflation rate that persists over a very long time.

static.solution:
1. The answer is B, because the speed of the car is constant, and then decreases linearly when the breaks are applied uniformly.
2. The answer is C, because the ingot will get hot and then cool off, so the temperature will increase and then decrease.
3. The answer is A, because Carbon-14 decays exponentially.
4. The answer is D, because the petri dish can only sustain the population up to a certain size. The population will grow until it reaches this limiting value.
5. The answer is E, because the cost of the product, in the absence of any change in inflation, increases exponentially.

statement.p: Let A and k be positive constants.

static.solution: \frac{d}{dt} (A + C e^{-kt}) = -k C e^{-kt}, so that, plugging in, we have -k C e^{-kt} = k(A - A + Ce^{-kt}), a true statement, so that the correct answer is y = A + C e^{-kt}.

Match the solutions to the differential equations. If there is more than one solution to an equation, select the answer that includes all solutions.

li.p: y = e^{-6 x} or y = e^{6 x}

static.solution:
\frac{d}{dx} (e^{-6 x}) = -6 e^{-6 x},
\frac{d^2}{dx^2} (e^{-6 x}) = 36 e^{-6 x},
\frac{d}{dx} (e^{6 x}) = 6 e^{-6 x},
\frac{d^2}{dx^2} (e^{-6 x}) = 36 e^{-6 x},
\frac{d}{dx} (\sin(6 x)) = 6 \cos(6 x),
\frac{d^2}{dx^2} (\sin(6 x)) = -36 \sin(6 x),
\frac{d}{dx} (6 \sin(x)) = 6 \cos(x), and
\frac{d^2}{dx^2} (6 \sin(x)) = -6 \sin(6 x).
Thus, the correct answers are:
\frac{dy}{dx}=6 y : E,
\frac{d^2y}{dx^2}=-36 y : F,
\frac{d^2y}{dx^2}=36 y : A, and
\frac{dy}{dx}=-6 y : B

statement.p: Fill in the missing values in the table given if you know that dy/dt=0.8 y. Assume the rate of growth given by dy/dt is approximately constant over each unit time interval and that the initial value of y is 6.

static.solution:
t=0 the value of y is 6. Since we are told that dy/dt=0.8 y, we know that at time t=0 the derivative of y is 0.8 (6) = 4.8. Thus as t goes from 0 to 1, y will increase by 4.8, so at t=1, y=6 + 4.8 = 10.8.
Likewise, at t=1, we get {dy}/{dt} = 0.8 (10.8)=8.64 so that at t=2, we obtain y=10.8 + 8.64 = 19.44.
At t=2, we have dy/dt=0.8 (19.44)=15.552 so that at t=3, we obtain y=19.44 + 15.552 = 34.992.
Continuing similarly, dy/dt|_{t=3} = 27.9936, so that at t=4 we have y = 34.992 + 27.9936 = 62.9856.

static.solution: \displaystyle{\frac{dy}{dt} = t-2} gives the slope of the solution curve as a function of time, so the t-coordinate of any point on the solution curve determines the slope of the tangent line to the curve at that point.

statement.p: Consider the initial value problem \displaystyle{\frac{dy}{dt} = \frac{1}{2}(y+1)}, where y(0)=0.
Use the differential equation to find the slope of the tangent line to the solution curve y=y(t) at t = 0.
Slope =
Use the given initial value to find the equation of the tangent line to the solution curve at t = 0.
Use the equation of the tangent line that you just found to approximate y(2), the value of the solution at t=2.
Assuming that your approximation for y(2) is the actual value of y(2), use the differential equation to find the slope of the tangent line to y=y(t) at t = 2.
Slope =
Use the slope that you just found to find an approximate equation of the tangent line to the solution curve at t = 2.
Use the equation of the tangent line that you just found to approximate y(4), the value of the solution at t=4.

static.solution: y, we can compute the slope of the tangent line using the formula for dy/dt. So given a value of t, we must first compute (or approximate) a value of y. When t=0, the initial condition tells us that y=0, so the corresponding slope is \frac{1}{2}(0+1) = \frac{1}{2} and the equation of the tangent line is y=\frac{1}{2}t. Now when t=2, we can use this tangent line equation to approximate y \approx \frac{1}{2}\cdot 2 =1, and then we can use this approximate value of y to approximate the slope to be \frac{1}{2}(1+1). In point-slope form, the tangent line to the solution curve at t=2 is approximately y\approx 1(t-2)+1, and so y(4) \approx 3.
